context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Two families hid in pools during the California fires, and their stories end in very different ways
context_meta.summary: The wildfires ravaging California have been devastating this week, with over 30 people dead so far and countless of homes have been destroyed.  While countless of stories are coming from the Golden State, two families shared horrifying accounts of hiding in their respective pools for safety until the flames have passed.  SEE ALSO: California wildfire victims returning to their destroyed homes is absolutely heart-wrenching "In my naïveté, all night long,” Jan Pascoe told the LA Times, "I thought someone would come to get us."  The 65-year-old was trapped with her 70-year-old husband, John, for six hours, hiding in the pool after their attempt to evacuate was met with "a wall of flames" and were forced to turn back.  "I just kept going under,” she told the newspaper. "And I kept saying, ‘How long does it take for a house to burn down?’ We were freezing."  Once the fire passed, they managed to escape. “We held hands,” John explained, “and walked out.”  Despite the close call, the Pascoes both survived and were reunited with their children shortly after the fire had passed. All of their belongings were demolished in the fire. Unfortunately, the Berriz family had a very different ending to their story. Carmen and Armando Berriz were married for 55 years and according to SF Gate, the husband and wife clung to each other in a pool for hours as well, until Carmen stopped breathing and passed in Armando's arms. Their family had been in Santa Rosa on vacation, and after their son, Luis Ocon, noticed flames were encroaching their residence, everyone evacuated as quickly as possible.   Armando tripped on a tree which slowed him and his wife down considerably, so much so that their best option was to return to the home and find refuge in the pool. Armando was able to walk two miles to find a firefighter, and was reunited with his family.  “He’s had a rough time,” Luis Ocon told SF Gate, explaining that Armando was back in his home in Apple Valley. “But he’s unbelievably strong.” You can read more about the life of Carmen Berriz here, and you can learn more about how you can support victims of the fires here.  WATCH: The science behind the fast-moving wildfires that are devastating California

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Two families hid in pools during the California fires, and their stories end in very different ways
context_meta.summary: The wildfires ravaging California have been devastating this week, with over 30 people dead so far and countless of homes have been destroyed.  While countless of stories are coming from the Golden State, two families shared horrifying accounts of hiding in their respective pools for safety until the flames have passed.  SEE ALSO: California wildfire victims returning to their destroyed homes is absolutely heart-wrenching "In my naïveté, all night long,” Jan Pascoe told the LA Times, "I thought someone would come to get us."  The 65-year-old was trapped with her 70-year-old husband, John, for six hours, hiding in the pool after their attempt to evacuate was met with "a wall of flames" and were forced to turn back.  "I just kept going under,” she told the newspaper. "And I kept saying, ‘How long does it take for a house to burn down?’ We were freezing."  Once the fire passed, they managed to escape. “We held hands,” John explained, “and walked out.”  Despite the close call, the Pascoes both survived and were reunited with their children shortly after the fire had passed. All of their belongings were demolished in the fire. Unfortunately, the Berriz family had a very different ending to their story. Carmen and Armando Berriz were married for 55 years and according to SF Gate, the husband and wife clung to each other in a pool for hours as well, until Carmen stopped breathing and passed in Armando's arms. Their family had been in Santa Rosa on vacation, and after their son, Luis Ocon, noticed flames were encroaching their residence, everyone evacuated as quickly as possible.   Armando tripped on a tree which slowed him and his wife down considerably, so much so that their best option was to return to the home and find refuge in the pool. Armando was able to walk two miles to find a firefighter, and was reunited with his family.  “He’s had a rough time,” Luis Ocon told SF Gate, explaining that Armando was back in his home in Apple Valley. “But he’s unbelievably strong.” You can read more about the life of Carmen Berriz here, and you can learn more about how you can support victims of the fires here.  WATCH: The science behind the fast-moving wildfires that are devastating California

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Two families hid in pools during the California fires, and their stories end in very different ways
context_meta.summary: The wildfires ravaging California have been devastating this week, with over 30 people dead so far and countless of homes have been destroyed.  While countless of stories are coming from the Golden State, two families shared horrifying accounts of hiding in their respective pools for safety until the flames have passed.  SEE ALSO: California wildfire victims returning to their destroyed homes is absolutely heart-wrenching "In my naïveté, all night long,” Jan Pascoe told the LA Times, "I thought someone would come to get us."  The 65-year-old was trapped with her 70-year-old husband, John, for six hours, hiding in the pool after their attempt to evacuate was met with "a wall of flames" and were forced to turn back.  "I just kept going under,” she told the newspaper. "And I kept saying, ‘How long does it take for a house to burn down?’ We were freezing."  Once the fire passed, they managed to escape. “We held hands,” John explained, “and walked out.”  Despite the close call, the Pascoes both survived and were reunited with their children shortly after the fire had passed. All of their belongings were demolished in the fire. Unfortunately, the Berriz family had a very different ending to their story. Carmen and Armando Berriz were married for 55 years and according to SF Gate, the husband and wife clung to each other in a pool for hours as well, until Carmen stopped breathing and passed in Armando's arms. Their family had been in Santa Rosa on vacation, and after their son, Luis Ocon, noticed flames were encroaching their residence, everyone evacuated as quickly as possible.   Armando tripped on a tree which slowed him and his wife down considerably, so much so that their best option was to return to the home and find refuge in the pool. Armando was able to walk two miles to find a firefighter, and was reunited with his family.  “He’s had a rough time,” Luis Ocon told SF Gate, explaining that Armando was back in his home in Apple Valley. “But he’s unbelievably strong.” You can read more about the life of Carmen Berriz here, and you can learn more about how you can support victims of the fires here.  WATCH: The science behind the fast-moving wildfires that are devastating California

text: In 2005 I went to Kenya on a humanitarian mission. We landed in Nairobi and everything was green and food was everywhere. We then got on a small plane and flew to northern Kenya. It was a desert of rocks and small bushes and people were fighting each other to get  small bags of corn we were passing out. I started noticing the small huts these people were living in had roofs made from bags that said USA food aid on the side. I asked around and figured out that the USA has been supporting these people for decades while their own government was exporting the food grown in the south to other countries. I asked how they would feed their 5+ children if the food shipment stopped and they had no clue and were panicking at the thought that that could happen. We are not doing these people any favors by artificially creating an environment were it is OK to have 5+ kids that you cannot feed. So unless you plan on continuing and increasing your help to the poor every year to take care of all the children they think they can have with your help, don't start. I know it sounds mean but that is the reality.

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Two families hid in pools during the California fires, and their stories end in very different ways
context_meta.summary: The wildfires ravaging California have been devastating this week, with over 30 people dead so far and countless of homes have been destroyed.  While countless of stories are coming from the Golden State, two families shared horrifying accounts of hiding in their respective pools for safety until the flames have passed.  SEE ALSO: California wildfire victims returning to their destroyed homes is absolutely heart-wrenching "In my naïveté, all night long,” Jan Pascoe told the LA Times, "I thought someone would come to get us."  The 65-year-old was trapped with her 70-year-old husband, John, for six hours, hiding in the pool after their attempt to evacuate was met with "a wall of flames" and were forced to turn back.  "I just kept going under,” she told the newspaper. "And I kept saying, ‘How long does it take for a house to burn down?’ We were freezing."  Once the fire passed, they managed to escape. “We held hands,” John explained, “and walked out.”  Despite the close call, the Pascoes both survived and were reunited with their children shortly after the fire had passed. All of their belongings were demolished in the fire. Unfortunately, the Berriz family had a very different ending to their story. Carmen and Armando Berriz were married for 55 years and according to SF Gate, the husband and wife clung to each other in a pool for hours as well, until Carmen stopped breathing and passed in Armando's arms. Their family had been in Santa Rosa on vacation, and after their son, Luis Ocon, noticed flames were encroaching their residence, everyone evacuated as quickly as possible.   Armando tripped on a tree which slowed him and his wife down considerably, so much so that their best option was to return to the home and find refuge in the pool. Armando was able to walk two miles to find a firefighter, and was reunited with his family.  “He’s had a rough time,” Luis Ocon told SF Gate, explaining that Armando was back in his home in Apple Valley. “But he’s unbelievably strong.” You can read more about the life of Carmen Berriz here, and you can learn more about how you can support victims of the fires here.  WATCH: The science behind the fast-moving wildfires that are devastating California

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Two families hid in pools during the California fires, and their stories end in very different ways
context_meta.summary: The wildfires ravaging California have been devastating this week, with over 30 people dead so far and countless of homes have been destroyed.  While countless of stories are coming from the Golden State, two families shared horrifying accounts of hiding in their respective pools for safety until the flames have passed.  SEE ALSO: California wildfire victims returning to their destroyed homes is absolutely heart-wrenching "In my naïveté, all night long,” Jan Pascoe told the LA Times, "I thought someone would come to get us."  The 65-year-old was trapped with her 70-year-old husband, John, for six hours, hiding in the pool after their attempt to evacuate was met with "a wall of flames" and were forced to turn back.  "I just kept going under,” she told the newspaper. "And I kept saying, ‘How long does it take for a house to burn down?’ We were freezing."  Once the fire passed, they managed to escape. “We held hands,” John explained, “and walked out.”  Despite the close call, the Pascoes both survived and were reunited with their children shortly after the fire had passed. All of their belongings were demolished in the fire. Unfortunately, the Berriz family had a very different ending to their story. Carmen and Armando Berriz were married for 55 years and according to SF Gate, the husband and wife clung to each other in a pool for hours as well, until Carmen stopped breathing and passed in Armando's arms. Their family had been in Santa Rosa on vacation, and after their son, Luis Ocon, noticed flames were encroaching their residence, everyone evacuated as quickly as possible.   Armando tripped on a tree which slowed him and his wife down considerably, so much so that their best option was to return to the home and find refuge in the pool. Armando was able to walk two miles to find a firefighter, and was reunited with his family.  “He’s had a rough time,” Luis Ocon told SF Gate, explaining that Armando was back in his home in Apple Valley. “But he’s unbelievably strong.” You can read more about the life of Carmen Berriz here, and you can learn more about how you can support victims of the fires here.  WATCH: The science behind the fast-moving wildfires that are devastating California

The union has sent 40 nurses to Puerto Rico, where the natural disaster of Hurricane Maria and neglect from the Trump administration has created a perfect storm of death, disease and decay across an island of 3.4 million American citizens.

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Two families hid in pools during the California fires, and their stories end in very different ways
context_meta.summary: The wildfires ravaging California have been devastating this week, with over 30 people dead so far and countless of homes have been destroyed.  While countless of stories are coming from the Golden State, two families shared horrifying accounts of hiding in their respective pools for safety until the flames have passed.  SEE ALSO: California wildfire victims returning to their destroyed homes is absolutely heart-wrenching "In my naïveté, all night long,” Jan Pascoe told the LA Times, "I thought someone would come to get us."  The 65-year-old was trapped with her 70-year-old husband, John, for six hours, hiding in the pool after their attempt to evacuate was met with "a wall of flames" and were forced to turn back.  "I just kept going under,” she told the newspaper. "And I kept saying, ‘How long does it take for a house to burn down?’ We were freezing."  Once the fire passed, they managed to escape. “We held hands,” John explained, “and walked out.”  Despite the close call, the Pascoes both survived and were reunited with their children shortly after the fire had passed. All of their belongings were demolished in the fire. Unfortunately, the Berriz family had a very different ending to their story. Carmen and Armando Berriz were married for 55 years and according to SF Gate, the husband and wife clung to each other in a pool for hours as well, until Carmen stopped breathing and passed in Armando's arms. Their family had been in Santa Rosa on vacation, and after their son, Luis Ocon, noticed flames were encroaching their residence, everyone evacuated as quickly as possible.   Armando tripped on a tree which slowed him and his wife down considerably, so much so that their best option was to return to the home and find refuge in the pool. Armando was able to walk two miles to find a firefighter, and was reunited with his family.  “He’s had a rough time,” Luis Ocon told SF Gate, explaining that Armando was back in his home in Apple Valley. “But he’s unbelievably strong.” You can read more about the life of Carmen Berriz here, and you can learn more about how you can support victims of the fires here.  WATCH: The science behind the fast-moving wildfires that are devastating California

Armando was able to walk two miles to find a firefighter, and was reunited with his family.  “He’s had a rough time,” Luis Ocon told SF Gate, explaining that Armando was back in his home in Apple Valley. “But he’s unbelievably strong.” You can read more about the life of Carmen Berriz here, and you can learn more about how you can support victims of the fires here.  WATCH: The science behind the fast-moving wildfires that are devastating California

context_meta.title: Two families hid in pools during the California fires, and their stories end in very different ways
context_meta.summary: The wildfires ravaging California have been devastating this week, with over 30 people dead so far and countless of homes have been destroyed.  While countless of stories are coming from the Golden State, two families shared horrifying accounts of hiding in their respective pools for safety until the flames have passed.  SEE ALSO: California wildfire victims returning to their destroyed homes is absolutely heart-wrenching "In my naïveté, all night long,” Jan Pascoe told the LA Times, "I thought someone would come to get us."  The 65-year-old was trapped with her 70-year-old husband, John, for six hours, hiding in the pool after their attempt to evacuate was met with "a wall of flames" and were forced to turn back.  "I just kept going under,” she told the newspaper. "And I kept saying, ‘How long does it take for a house to burn down?’ We were freezing."  Once the fire passed, they managed to escape. “We held hands,” John explained, “and walked out.”  Despite the close call, the Pascoes both survived and were reunited with their children shortly after the fire had passed. All of their belongings were demolished in the fire. Unfortunately, the Berriz family had a very different ending to their story. Carmen and Armando Berriz were married for 55 years and according to SF Gate, the husband and wife clung to each other in a pool for hours as well, until Carmen stopped breathing and passed in Armando's arms. Their family had been in Santa Rosa on vacation, and after their son, Luis Ocon, noticed flames were encroaching their residence, everyone evacuated as quickly as possible.   Armando tripped on a tree which slowed him and his wife down considerably, so much so that their best option was to return to the home and find refuge in the pool. Armando was able to walk two miles to find a firefighter, and was reunited with his family.  “He’s had a rough time,” Luis Ocon told SF Gate, explaining that Armando was back in his home in Apple Valley. “But he’s unbelievably strong.” You can read more about the life of Carmen Berriz here, and you can learn more about how you can support victims of the fires here.  WATCH: The science behind the fast-moving wildfires that are devastating California

context_meta.title: Two families hid in pools during the California fires, and their stories end in very different ways
context_meta.summary: The wildfires ravaging California have been devastating this week, with over 30 people dead so far and countless of homes have been destroyed.  While countless of stories are coming from the Golden State, two families shared horrifying accounts of hiding in their respective pools for safety until the flames have passed.  SEE ALSO: California wildfire victims returning to their destroyed homes is absolutely heart-wrenching "In my naïveté, all night long,” Jan Pascoe told the LA Times, "I thought someone would come to get us."  The 65-year-old was trapped with her 70-year-old husband, John, for six hours, hiding in the pool after their attempt to evacuate was met with "a wall of flames" and were forced to turn back.  "I just kept going under,” she told the newspaper. "And I kept saying, ‘How long does it take for a house to burn down?’ We were freezing."  Once the fire passed, they managed to escape. “We held hands,” John explained, “and walked out.”  Despite the close call, the Pascoes both survived and were reunited with their children shortly after the fire had passed. All of their belongings were demolished in the fire. Unfortunately, the Berriz family had a very different ending to their story. Carmen and Armando Berriz were married for 55 years and according to SF Gate, the husband and wife clung to each other in a pool for hours as well, until Carmen stopped breathing and passed in Armando's arms. Their family had been in Santa Rosa on vacation, and after their son, Luis Ocon, noticed flames were encroaching their residence, everyone evacuated as quickly as possible.   Armando tripped on a tree which slowed him and his wife down considerably, so much so that their best option was to return to the home and find refuge in the pool. Armando was able to walk two miles to find a firefighter, and was reunited with his family.  “He’s had a rough time,” Luis Ocon told SF Gate, explaining that Armando was back in his home in Apple Valley. “But he’s unbelievably strong.” You can read more about the life of Carmen Berriz here, and you can learn more about how you can support victims of the fires here.  WATCH: The science behind the fast-moving wildfires that are devastating California

In his first speech at the United Nations, U.S. President Donald Trump personally attacked North Korean leader Kim Jong-un and threatened to “totally destroy North Korea.” In response, in what is believed to be the first direct statement issued to the world under his name, Kim declared that he would “tame the mentally deranged U.S. dotard with fire.” North Korean foreign minister Ri Yong-ho suggested a hydrogen-bomb test over the Pacific Ocean as a possible countermeasure of the young dictator to Trump’s insult.

text:
Few people remember this, but in 1994 President Clinton had a similar deal in place with North Korea. It was called the "Agreed Framework". In it Pyongyang agreed to limit their nuclear weapons program in exchange for shipments of fuel and a non-weaponize-able nuclear reactor. While there was a missile test in 1998 that triggered some re negotiations, this was a path to peace where both sides were able to sit down.

In 2002, George W. Bush, against the advice of Colin Powell, pulled us out of the deal. Fuel shipments ceased and Bush began using the "axis of evil" label for Kim Jong Il's regime. This damaged relations to the point North Korea believe the US would never honor any agreement they made at the table, understandably so.

Now, we have a Secretary of State who has had open conflict with the President. It is tough for a foreign nation to believe that Tillerson holds the President's ear anymore, and have little incentive to sitting with him to make a deal. We also have a President who has decided to pull out and ignore numerous longstanding deals and negotiations (NAFTA, The Paris Agreement, NATO, TPP, etc)

Pulling out of the Iran deal could be the final step to North Korea realizing there will never be any diplomatic relations with the US and the only response will be war.

(Source: https://www.armscontrol.org/factsheets/agreedframework)

About 46 percent of Republicans support a preemptive strike on North Korea today—compare that with just 42 percent of Republicans who say they don't support it, according to a new Quinnipiac University poll. Only 16 percent of Democrats favor the idea of the U.S. making a preemptive strike on North Korea, while a whopping 77 percent of Democrats oppose it.

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: America Could Subdue North Korea's Nuclear Threats with a Not-So-Grand Bargain
context_meta.summary: A double-freeze deal will not be satisfying to either U.S. or North Korean leaders, but it still reduces tensions and the risk of accidental nuclear war. In the escalating crisis between the United States and North Korea, the world can no longer afford to wait for a grand bargain to emerge. In his first speech at the United Nations, U.S. President Donald Trump personally attacked North Korean leader Kim Jong-un and threatened to “totally destroy North Korea.” In response, in what is believed to be the first direct statement issued to the world under his name, Kim declared that he would “tame the mentally deranged U.S. dotard with fire.” North Korean foreign minister Ri Yong-ho suggested a hydrogen-bomb test over the Pacific Ocean as a possible countermeasure of the young dictator to Trump’s insult.
